repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Third Adaptable Program Loan for
            Energy Community of South East Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Adaptable Program
            Loan (APL) for Energy Community of South East Europe Project
            for Turkey were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            creating a formal project identity for regional engagements
            will enhance visibility and accountability within the Bank
            for operations involving complex regional dialogue and
            structures. As there is no formal lending relationship
            underpinning the energy community dialogue between the Bank
            and regional apex institutions, there is no formal project
            identity, budgeting and direct accountability within the
            formal Bank system for effective regional dialogue.
            Fortunately this does not appear to have been a serious
            problem to date, given steady and strong management support
            and continuity in staffing assignments. Upfront approval of
            an APL facility can help solidify both Bank and client
            commitment and cooperation around a sectoral or regional
            agenda. While the APL instrument offered little streamlining
            in processing of individual operations, the upfront approval
            of the US$ 1 billion APL facility provided strong evidence
            of Bank commitment and helped increase the credibility of
            the energy community ahead of the signing and effectiveness
            of the treaty.

Turkey - Third Adaptable Program Loan for
            Energy Community of South East Europe Project

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey’s energy reforms for a sustainable
            energy future

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            Turkey's reforms for a sustainable energy future.
            Turkey faced increasing domestic energy demand and rapidly
            growing greenhouse gas emissions, a large portion of which
            come from energy production and usage. International Bank
            for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has supported
            Turkey’s energy reforms significantly over the last decade
            by utilizing the full range of World Bank lending and
            technical support in ways that complement and reinforce each
            other. The government of Turkey, with IBRD support, has
            transformed its energy sector to increase competition,
            expand private investment and promote sustainable use of its
            renewable energy resources. Turkey has improved the
            efficiency of its electricity market while increasing
            private sector participation in power distribution and
            generation. The World Bank’s work has helped in attracting
            large-scale private investment, particularly in renewable
            resources. Significant new financing has been brought in to
            support new investments in generation, and also in
            privatized distribution. Turkey’s energy sector has
            transformed from one that was monolithic and state-owned
            into a commercially run and liberalized market, with private
            investment and ownership in several parts of the sector.

docna.cdata!:
Turkey’s energy reforms for a sustainable
            energy future

display_title.display_title:
Turkey’s energy reforms for a
            sustainable energy future
